discussion.content: Correct

Is this question old?

From https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-netapp-files/snapshots-manage-policy I can see that step 2 should be "Create a snapshot policy" and step 3 should be "Apply a snapshot policy to a volume". But what is step 1?

I cannot find any reference in the docs that say you need to register either the NetApp Resource Provider (should already be registered since the question says we're already using ANF) or the snapshot policy feature (unless this WAS required before and no longer the case)?

And obviously we don't need to create an Azure NetApp account since we're already using ANF.

Register snapshot policy
Create snapshot policy
Apply snapshot policy
Got this on exam today.

Correct Register, Create Policy, Apply Policy to Volume.

Register-AzProviderFeature -ProviderNamespace Microsoft.NetApp -FeatureName ANFSnapshotPolicy

You have an Azure Virtual Desktop deployment.
You deploy and configure Azure Virtual Desktop in a secondary location.
You plan to perform a test failover to the secondary location, but discover existing user sessions to the primary location.
You need to sign out users from the session hosts in the primary location.
Which PowerShell cmdlet should you run?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To sign out users from the session hosts in the primary location of your Azure Virtual Desktop deployment, you should use the Invoke-RdsUserSessionLogoff cmdlet. This cmdlet allows you to log off user sessions from a specified session host.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

A. Invoke-RdsUserSessionLogoff.


The cmdlet Remove-AzWvdUserSession is not the correct choice because it is not designed for logging off user sessions. Instead, it is used for removing user sessions from the Azure Virtual Desktop environment, which is not the same as logging off users.

The Invoke-RdsUserSessionLogoff cmdlet is specifically designed to log off user sessions from a specified session host, which is what you need to do in this scenario.

Selected Answer: B
B. Remove-AzWvdUserSession

Selected Answer: B
If there are existing user connections during the outage, before the admin can start failover to the secondary region, you need to end the user connections in the current region.

To disconnect users in Azure Virtual Desktop (classic), run this cmdlet: Invoke-RdsUserSessionLogoff

To disconnect users in the Azure-integrated version of Azure Virtual Desktop, run this cmdlet: Remove-AzWvdUserSession

Once youâ€™ve signed out all users in the primary region, you can fail over the VMs in the primary region and let users connect to the VMs in the secondary region

Selected Answer: B
B is correct - providing AVD deployment is not classic mode.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-desktop/disaster-recovery

Yes it's correct.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.desktopvirtualization/remove-azwvdusersession?view=azps-6.6.0

choices.A: the Diagnostic settings of the host pool

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Virtual Desktop deployment.
You use the Start/Stop VMs during off-hours feature in Azure.
You need to configure which virtual machines must never be stopped by the solution.
What should you configure?

choices.B: Create a virtual machine snapshot of each session host.
choices.C: Create an Azure Storage account that uses geo-redundant storage (GRS).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Creating a Recovery Services vault (Option A) is indeed the correct first step. This vault is essential for setting up disaster recovery and ensuring that your host pool can fail over to another region.

Selected Answer: A
A. Create a Recovery Services vault.

Selected Answer: A
You can configure replication for all your VMs in both pooled and personal host pools with Azure Site Recovery. For more information about how this process works, see Replicate Azure VMs to another Azure region
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-desktop/disaster-recovery#vm-replication
A is correct. The replication is from VM for that reason we use a Recovery Services vault

Selected Answer: A
A is correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
You will need an Recovery Services vault for this:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/backup/backup-azure-recovery-services-vault-overview

comments.content:
C is not possible. With choosing an Azure Storage account that is GRS redundant you have a highly available storage account which indeed is available in another region. This will not failover the hostpool itself.

You will need an Recovery Services vault for this:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/backup/backup-azure-recovery-services-vault-overview

discussion.content:
I think it's the answer C. Because 
Data is synchronously applied three times in the primary region using Redundant Local Storage (LRS), and then applied asynchronously in the secondary region. For read access to data in the secondary region, enable geo-redundant storage with read access (RA-GRS).
correct

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Virtual Desktop host pool in the US East Azure region.
You need to ensure that the host pool can fail over to the US West Azure region.
What should you do first?

discussion.content:
One of the requirements: Before migrating the RDS deployment in the Seattle office, obtain the recommended deployment configuration based on the current RDS utilization.
Lakeside does the work.

correct. 

"Run a discovery of your on-premises datacenter using Lakeside, an integrated ISV tool in Azure Migrate. Lakeside will collect performance information using clients installed on on-premises virtual desktops."

https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/azure-migration-and/migrate-virtual-desktops-to-azure/ba-p/1361120
Answer is correct.
Correcto~
